segments.en: Linked Discourses 3
2. Childless
20. Childless (2nd)

segments.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo divā divassa yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha in the middle of the day … The Buddha said to him,

segments.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, mahārāja, āgacchasi divā divassā”ti?
segments.en: “So, great king, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”
“Sir, here in Sāvatthī a financier householder has passed away.

segments.pli: Tamahaṃ aputtakaṃ sāpateyyaṃ rājantepuraṃ atiharitvā āgacchāmi.
segments.en: Since he died childless, I have come after transferring his fortune to the royal compound.

segments.pli: Sataṃ, bhante, satasahassāni hiraññasseva, ko pana vādo rūpiyassa.
segments.en: There was ten million in gold, not to mention the silver.

segments.pli: Tassa kho pana, bhante, seṭṭhissa gahapatissa evarūpo bhattabhogo ahosi—
segments.en: And yet that financier ate meals of
rough gruel with pickles.
He wore clothes consisting of
three pieces of sunn hemp.
He traveled around in a vehicle that was
a dilapidated little cart, holding a leaf as sunshade.”
“That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ so, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati taggarasikhiṃ nāma paccekasambuddhaṃ piṇḍapātena paṭipādesi.
segments.en: Once upon a time, great king, that financier householder provided alms-food on behalf of a Buddha awakened for himself named Tagarasikhī.
He instructed: ‘Give alms to that ascetic,’ before getting up from his seat and leaving.

segments.pli: Datvā ca pana pacchā vippaṭisārī ahosi:
segments.en: But after giving he regretted it:

segments.pli: ‘varametaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ dāsā vā kammakarā vā bhuñjeyyun’ti.
segments.en: ‘It would have been better to feed the bondservants or workers with that alms-food.’

segments.pli: Bhātu ca pana ekaputtakaṃ sāpateyyassa kāraṇā jīvitā voropesi.
segments.en: What’s more, he murdered his brother’s only child for the sake of his fortune.

segments.pli: Yaṃ kho so, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati taggarasikhiṃ paccekasambuddhaṃ piṇḍapātena paṭipādesi, tassa kammassa vipākena sattakkhattuṃ sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajji.
segments.en: Because that financier provided Tagarasikhī with alms-food, as a result of that deed he was reborn seven times in a good place, a heavenly realm.

segments.pli: Tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesena imissāyeva sāvatthiyā sattakkhattuṃ seṭṭhittaṃ kāresi.
segments.en: And as a residual result of that same deed he held the position of financier seven times right here in Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Yaṃ kho so, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati datvā pacchā vippaṭisārī ahosi:
segments.en: But because that financier regretted giving alms,

segments.pli: ‘varametaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ dāsā vā kammakarā vā bhuñjeyyun’ti, tassa kammassa vipākena nāssuḷārāya bhattabhogāya cittaṃ namati, nāssuḷārāya vatthabhogāya cittaṃ namati, nāssuḷārāya yānabhogāya cittaṃ namati, nāssuḷārānaṃ pañcannaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ bhogāya cittaṃ namati.
segments.en: as a result of that deed his mind didn’t tend to enjoy nice food, clothes, vehicles, or the five refined kinds of sensual stimulation.

segments.pli: Yaṃ kho so, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati bhātu ca pana ekaputtakaṃ sāpateyyassa kāraṇā jīvitā voropesi, tassa kammassa vipākena bahūni vassāni bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni bahūni vassasatasahassāni niraye paccittha.
segments.en: And because that financier murdered his brother’s only child for the sake of his fortune, as a result of that deed he burned in hell for many years, for many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of years.

segments.pli: Tasseva kammassa vipākāvasesena idaṃ sattamaṃ aputtakaṃ sāpateyyaṃ rājakosaṃ paveseti.
segments.en: And as a residual result of that same deed for the seventh time, since he is childless, his fortune ends up in the royal treasury.

segments.pli: Tassa kho, mahārāja, seṭṭhissa gahapatissa purāṇañca puññaṃ parikkhīṇaṃ, navañca puññaṃ anupacitaṃ.
segments.en: Now the old merit of that financier has been used up, and he hasn’t accumulated new merit.

segments.pli: Ajja pana, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati mahāroruve niraye paccatī”ti.
segments.en: Today, great king, that financier burns in the Great Hell of Screams.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante, seṭṭhi gahapati mahāroruvaṃ nirayaṃ upapanno”ti.
segments.en: “So, sir, that financier has been reborn in the Great Hell of Screams?”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, mahārāja, seṭṭhi gahapati mahāroruvaṃ nirayaṃ upapanno”ti.
segments.en: “Yes he has, great king.”
That is what the Buddha said. …
“Grain, wealth, silver, and gold,
or whatever other possessions there are;
bondservants, workers, employees,
and those dependent for their livelihood:
you must go on without taking these;
all of them are left behind.
But the deeds you do
by body, speech, and mind—
that’s what you can call your own.
That’s what you take when you go.
That’s what goes with you,
like a shadow that never leaves.
That’s why you should do good,
investing in the future life.
The good deeds of sentient beings
support them in the next world.”

suttaplex.blurb: A wealthy man dies childless, having not enjoyed his riches. The Buddha tells of how in the time of a solitary Buddha of the past named Tagarasikhī, a householder made an offering but later regretted it.
